intro.title: How Should I Study the Bible?
intro.description: The Bible may seem confusing and hard to be understood, but it is not. There are simple tips that can help you to easily understand the Bible and get the most from its teachings. However, since long ago people have had a hard time understanding the Scriptures.

appendix.appendixContent:
Acts 8:30-35

30 So Philip ran to him, and heard him reading the prophet Isaiah, and said, “Do you understand what you are reading?”31 And he said, “How can I, unless someone guides me?” And he asked Philip to come up and sit with him.32 The place in the Scripture which he read was this: “He was led as a sheep to the slaughter; And as a lamb before its shearer is silent, So He opened not His mouth.33 In His humiliation His justice was taken away, And who will declare His generation? For His life is taken from the earth.”34 So the eunuch answered Philip and said, “I ask you, of whom does the prophet say this, of himself or of some other man?”35 Then Philip opened his mouth, and beginning at this Scripture, preached Jesus to him.

questions.description: In Acts 8:30-35 we find the story of the apostle Philip going after an Ethiopian that was reading the Scriptures but did not comprehend them. Philip’s help was required for the Ethiopian to have a better understanding of what he had just read. Such story shows us that reading the Bible and not understanding it is not something new. So, it is thought to be necessary to follow some guidelines that the Bible itself gives us about how to correctly study the Scriptures.

appendix.appendixContent:
Isaiah 28:10

10 For precept must be upon precept, precept upon precept, Line upon line, line upon line, Here a little, there a little.”

questions.description: In order to solve this problem, Philip’s story with the Ethiopian can help us. What did he do to explain the Bible? He used the Bible itself! That’s right. He began with the prophet Isaiah and showed how everything fit perfectly in the greater story that points to Jesus. That is also how the citizens of Berea studied and comprehended the Bible. According to Acts 17:11, they compared Bible texts with other Bible texts. This same principle also appears in the Old Testament, when Isaiah 28:10 says that “do” must be compared with “do” and “rule” with “rule”, being a “little here, a little there”. Therefore, portions of the Bible must be compared among themselves. Besides, the study of the Word of God requires a specific attitude from us so the study can be useful.

questions.description: Another important tip when studying the Bible is that it should be examined with humility and prayer so more than only being understood, its message can lead those who study it to have a real transformation in their lives (1 Corinthians 2:14 and Jeremiah 15:16).
